91.64.text: Harvard Business School, Ilya Strebulaev at

101.75.text: which basically got all the venture

104.69.text: capitalists in the world. So it's a very

106.37.text: nice survey. And I would say there are three

110.96.text: interesting. The first thing is, we asked

113.93.text: them, of the three key things

116.78.text: that you do, what's most important? And

119.09.text: what they do is they source deals, and

121.82.text: then from the deals that they source,

123.83.text: they select. And then from among those

126.56.text: that they select, then they help them.

130.10.text: was the most important? And surprisingly

133.22.text: to me, they said that selection was the

136.13.text: most important of those three. So that's

139.22.text: Two: we asked them, what was most important

144.26.text: in the deals that succeeded or failed,

150.92.text: selection process? And we basically gave

156.35.text: business." And, you know, I would say

166.78.text: the majority felt that the team was more

205.94.text: findings. There's a whole lot of other things, but—

411.84.text: [Wanner]: I would say there is the art. Venture

414.60.text: capital is an art versus a science. And I

417.30.text: think—Steve has alluded to this—I think

421.20.text: the team and the idea, and I do believe

423.90.text: that you have to demonstrate some kind

441.15.text: not surprise me that folks feel like the

443.49.text: idea, you know, is second to the people

448.77.text: capital is an art, and getting that mix

451.65.text: right and evaluating which components of

455.46.text: each of those sides you should process

464.22.text: here, and you'll see that successful

1371.79.text: through their network in some way. So

1373.53.text: generally, we would always recommend a

1375.42.text: warm introduction. Find an advisor for

1497.29.text: the fact that about half of the VCs said

1529.93.text: thinking about the investments I've made—

1680.64.text: This has been a fascinating discussion.
